The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It really helped me understand capital structure of company's and how that comes into play with investor's and manager's decisions.
I learned about a lot of the theoretical work around corporate finance, as well as the basics of the corporate finance field.
Great introduction to corporate finance: valuation, tradeoff theory, debt overhang, asymmetric information, agency problems, banking, bankruptcy, payout policy, financial crisis, etc.
Various aspects of corporate finance
I learned about capital structure, advantages and disadvantages of debt, agency problems (managerial incentives), payout policies, banking, and the financial crisis.
The backbone behind why some things occur in how corporations are managed (eg, how do you get managers to work hard, effect of debt, etc). Sort of like intermediate micro.
Deeper understanding of concepts concerning a firms capital structure
NPV, agency problems, asymmetric info, debt overhang, financial crisis, tax shield, equity vs. debt financing

I learned about the field of corporate finance broadly. Topics we covered: valuing a firm or project; debt and equity financing; debt overhang problems; assymetric information issues between firm manager vs. investors; the financial crisis and government bailouts. I learned how to use math (setting up equations, employing probability concepts, etc.) to represent or solve problems in the aforementioned topics. 

Some of the topics covered in this class also related to what is covered in game theory courses and microeconomics courses at Yale. I came in with a background in both, so corporate finance was particularly rewarding because it allowed me to revisit those topics.
I learned a very deep knowledge of corporate finance.
Corporate Finance theory and practice
important concepts in corporate finance such as debt vs. equity finance, DCF, managerial incentive compatibility, bankruptcy
Corporate Finance knowledge and skills
More extensive knowledge on bank business models, bailouts, agency problems, corporate structure.

Learned so so so much about different financing schemes (debt vs equity financing and the pros and cons associated with both), issues such as debt overhang, asymmetric information and how corporations get over that.

I learned important problems firms can run into and what solutions exist in terms of funding and bankruptcy.  I also learned what decisions governments must make in terms of bankruptcies an bailing out banks.
An understanding of how companies finance themselves ie with debt, equity
I learned corporate valuation concepts such as company valuation and the functions of debt and equity.

I learned a lot about the interior workings of a corporation, how corporations make financing decisions, what corporate finance is really about, and about corporate structure and law. I learned extensively about the place of debt in a corporation and how debt and equity interact in financing decisions.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Interesting topics discussed and very useful for anyone going into finance.
Weaknesses: Overly theoretical and not applied to real world situations to the extent that it should be.

The class did indeed cover some of the topics which are listed in the syllabus. However, not only did we not get to many of the later topics (which were marginally more interesting), but spend too much time on the theoretical aspects of the topics rather than exploring the functional real-world application of the topics.

Strengths: great introduction to real-world topics that anyone interested in going into business should know about. College students should really know more about this stuff, and I don't think there is any other Econ class that would teach you about this

Weaknesses: sometimes a little too theoretical (studying models without zooming out to look at big picture), lectures are a bit monotonous, there are few evaluations/assignments so everything is worth a large percentage of your grade
Well-organized

Prof Clayton is a great professor -- his lectures are very clear and he moves at a good pace. The psets are challenging, but doable and very rewarding once you figure out how to do them. The exams are also very fair (both take-home) and help you master the material. Overall, a wonderful class! One weakness may just be that the psets took a while to complete (I would recommend making them slightly shorter, perhaps 2 long problems instead of 3).

Strengths: Lectures and slides were good. Office hours were helpful
Weaknesses: OH were helpful but only twice a week. Didn't get to cover a lot of material because I felt like we spent too much time going over each concept. Would find it more interesting to look at data/numbers moreso than the micro models. Minor gripe: didn't grade homework on the document so it was kind of tedious to go and have to compare the answers and my homework. Psets felt really hard at times because the examples were not super similar to the lectures.
Good professor, interesting material. Lectures could be more engaging sometimes though.

The professor was great, and was always very clear in lecture and OH. The TA helped as well, and was always responsive in answering questions over email. Lectures in general were fine, but could be a bit dull at times--not really because of the professor but more so because some of the content. It's more theoretical than you might expect from a corporate finance course, and similar to other ECON courses at Yale. Problem sets are long but not too many of them, so it balances out.
Course was good. Maybe more examples

Professor Clayton and the TA Tianhao are extremely kind and always willing to help students understand concepts. I liked that there were four problem sets throughout the course (as opposed to weekly) because this gave students the time to digest the concepts before needing to work on them. I especially liked that the two exams (midterm and final) were take-home. This significantly reduced the stress associated with this course and created flexibility that was particularly fair due to COVID circumstances. 

I wish that problem sets would be returned with not just a final grade, but also with comments on where/why points were taken off. I also wished that we covered a wider breadth of topics in the course. For example, we spent over two lectures on banking, and over another two lectures on the financial crisis. This led to us not getting to the later half of the topics outlined in the syllabus. I wish that we used a short amount of time to cover those topics (because they are already discussed in depth in other econ courses) and instead took time to do other finance topics that we couldn't otherwise learn about at Yale that were in the syllabus: M&A, for example.
The lectures were incredible concise and the lecture slides were really really helpful. It would have been nice to have shorter psets more frequently.
Very engaging, well-planned lectures. Clayton is a gem
The strength of the course was the vast amount of material that you learn. However, the problem sets were often times challenging and much harder than what was taught in class.
Amazing course

Key strengths: the slides are very well organized, well-written, the presentation of them was efficient.

No major weaknesses.

I appreciated the pace of the lecturer, allowing one to take all of the notes in the allotted lecture time.  I do think that the homework and exams sometimes went beyond the scope of what we learned in class, so maybe that could be improved upon.
Problem sets didnt correlate with lecture material

It is a very bland topic and there's no way around it. But it is a useful topic to know and is presented clearly for the most part. Some of the examples we go over in class can be simplified or maybe we can spend a little more time dissecting the details of the examples for future classes.

It is a good introductory corporate finance course and teaches students the basics of corporate structure, which is very valuable and seems to be hard to come by. However, based on the syllabus, it seems that the course could be restructured a bit to cover all of the material, since our class did not get around to a significant portion of the topics on the syllabus (though perhaps this is because of difficulties due to the online format).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Eh
Nothing in particular
Sections complement lectures
More OH
Online lectures worked well - and they were recorded for if one missed a lecture
Well taught as a virtual class
I really liked that the exams were take-home. I also appreciated that lectures were recorded because not all students could attend live.
The recorded lectures and lecture slides were great.
No complaints
Great
Good structuring of the slides.
I really appreciated the recorded lectures as if I missed something or wanted to go over a lecture at a later time, I could easily do so, at my own pace.
The recording of lectures were good
The recorded lecture was very helpful as we can rewatch the lecture when we want to again.

The virtual course lectures were straightforward and were recorded and could be viewed later; students could ask questions in the chat without having to interrupt the instructor, which was helpful during the lecture.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Maybe. Hard to say. Useful to some extent, but also overly theoretical. Somewhat poorly organized in that there are only 4 psets, but they get stacked up at the end of the semester rather than being spread out.

If you want to learn about corporate finance with the goal of pursuing an academic career focused on finance, this could be a good introductory course, however, if you want to learn about the practical aspects of corporate finance and how it plays into the modern business world, this is not the class to do that.

Yes, this is a really great introduction to corporate finance. You don't need a ton of previous knowledge, and you will actually learn a ton over the semester. Anyone interesting in working in a for-profit company would benefit from knowing this stuff.
Yes, the porfessor is great

Yes definitely! Prof Clayton is a great instructor and the class content is super interesting and relevant (especially if you want to go into finance). The corporate finance knowledge I learned prepared me very well for banking interviews, and I'm so glad that I took this class.
Yes if you like micro. To be honest, I kind of thought that this course would be more excel work / case study based as opposed to solving mathematical models.
Yes - interesting and useful

Yeah, I probably would. It's more theoretical than I was expecting, but I think that's just how a lot of ECON courses are at Yale. I enjoyed Professor Clayton--he was always really nice and spoke well in lecture. Because there were only 4 problem sets this year, this class wasn't too bad in terms of workload, although the problem sets can take a while, and they aren't graded entirely on completion like some other courses. The two exams are relatively straightforward, but definitely took longer than the timeframe supposedly allotted for them, so they could potentially be difficult when this class is in person. Overall, a solid elective to take and pretty accessible to anyone studying ECON.
Yes, I learned a lot.

Yes, I'd recommend this course to another student if they were interested in finance. However, they should know that this course takes a theoretical, academic approach to understanding corporate finance. While we did cover some facts about the industry, that wasn't the focus of this course. Also, the student should be prepared that the problem sets (and exams) are not a straight-forward application of the lectures but rather require you to go beyond.
Yes 100% to learn Corp fin with a great professor
Yes.
If youre looking for a very theoretically rigorous, heavily economic model-based exploration of corporate finance, this is a great place to start
Yes, I would recommend this course to a student who is interested learning about corporate finance.
Yes anyone interested in finance should absolutely take this course
I recommend this course for anyone who wants to get deeper understanding of corporate finance
Yes, Prof. Clayton is great, and you learn quite a bit.
Yes! This was an amazing course and Chris is an amazing professor. I learned so much. The psets were super manageable and Chris is always down to answer any questions you have.
I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in the ways in which corporations finance themselves and the common issues they come across.
Only if you are truly interested in corporate finance theory. This won't help you with your finance internships.
No, it isnt applicable to real life finance
I will recommend the class to any economics major, as it is an important topic to know.

I would recommend it, and I would encourage students to ask questions about corporate structure and policy. The class seems to be designed as an introductory course and the professor is very patient with all types of questions.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

both live virtual and recorded
Live lectures were also recorded
Live virtual sections
Recorded + live
Section & office hours - all virtual
1) Twice-a-week recorded lectures (which could also be attended live); 2) Once-a-week 50-minute section with TA; 3) Optional weekly office hours with professor and TA
Some live lecture.
recorded zoom lecture

recorded lecture
live virtual lecture
There was office hours and discussion sessions that were not mandatory
Live virtual and recorded lectures
Recorded Lecture
Weekly section
Some live virtual lecture
Lectures were also recorded.
